channel.title: Network on TLDRBins
channel.description: Recent content in Network on TLDRBins

item.title: Firewall (Windows)
item.description: Check Firewall Rules # cmd cmd /c "netsh advfirewall firewall show rule name=all|findstr Name:" # powershell Get-NetFirewallProfile # Check outbound rules Get-NetFirewallRule -Direction Outbound -Enabled True # Pretty Print powershell -c "Get-NetFirewallRule -Direction Outbound -Enabled True -Action Block | Format-Table -Property DisplayName,@{Name='Protocol';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallPortFilter).Protocol}},@{Name='LocalPort';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallPortFilter).LocalPort}},@{Name='RemotePort';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallPortFilter).RemotePort}},@{Name='RemoteAddress';Expression={($PSItem | Get-NetFirewallAddressFilter).RemoteAddress}}, Enabled, Profile,Direction,Action" Add Inbound Rules # Allow all inbound traffic from local subnet New-NetFirewallRule -DisplayName "Allow All" -Direction Inbound -Enabled True -RemoteAddress LocalSubnet -Action Allow -Protocol TCP -Profile ANY

item.title: Network Discovery
item.description: Test Connectivity ping -c3 10.10.11.10 # Windows Test-NetConnection dc1 -Port 5985 Test Reverse Connectivity sudo tcpdump -ni tun0 icmp Sniff Network Traffic # For example: on port 389 tcpdump -i lo -nnXs 0 'port 389' mitmproxy # Sniff HTTPS traffic sudo ./mitmdump -p 443 --mode reverse:https://example.com --ssl-insecure --set flow_detail=3 Use ping to Scan Subnet for i in $(seq 1 254); do (ping -c 1 10.100.10.${i} | grep "bytes from" &); done; Use nc to Scan Ports for i in $(seq 1 65535); do (nc -zvn 127.

item.title: Network Traffic Pivoting
item.description: Chisel Download chisel Start a Local chisel Server # In our local Linux machine ./chisel server --reverse --port 8000 chisel with ports # In target machine ./chisel client 10.10.14.10:8000 R:8080:127.0.0.1:8080 # Mutiple ports fowarding, can be different targets in the same subnet ./chisel client 10.10.14.10:8000 R:8080:172.17.0.2:8080 R:5000:172.17.0.3:5000 chisel with socks5 # In our local Linux machine sudo nano /etc/proxychains4.conf # Add to the end of the file socks5 127.0.0.1 1080 # In target machine .

item.title: Nmap
item.description: Nmap Port Scan TCP Scan target=10.10.11.10 nmap -p- --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-alltcp $target ports=$(cat nmap-alltcp.nmap| grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//') nmap -p $ports -sCV -oA ./nmap-tcpscripts $target UDP Scan (common ports) target=10.10.11.10 nmap -sU --min-rate 10000 -oA ./nmap-udp $target ports=$(cat nmap-udp.nmap| grep -Eo "^[0-9]+" | tr '\n' ',' | sed -r 's/,$//') nmap -p $ports -sU -sCV -oA ./nmap-udpscripts $target Scan with nmap scripts Update scripts DB nmap --script-updatedb Search scripts nmap --script-help ftp* Scan with a script nmap --script=ftp-anon -sV -sC -p 21 10.
